item.title: Zohran Mamdani Is Sworn In as Mayor of New York City
item.description: Zohran Mamdani officially took office as mayor after the New Year’s Eve ball drop, in a private ceremony held at a shuttered relic of the city’s subway.
item.dc:creator: Dana Rubinstein
item.media:credit: Amir Hamja for The New York Times
item.media:description: Zohran Mamdani was officially sworn in as mayor of New York City at the old City Hall subway station early Thursday.

item.title: Mamdani Reverses Call to End Mayoral Control of NYC Public Schools
item.description: The mayor-elect’s turnaround came as he selected Kamar Samuels to lead New York City’s school system at a precarious moment.
item.dc:creator: Troy Closson
item.media:credit: James Estrin/The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani named Kamar Samuels as New York City’s schools chancellor. He starts on Thursday.

item.title: On His Last Day, Adams Drops From View but Still Flexes His Muscle
item.description: Mayor Eric Adams had one public appearance on his schedule, but that didn’t stop him from naming a third charter commission in the last hours of his administration.
item.dc:creator: Jeffery C. Mays
item.media:credit: Kent J. Edwards for The New York Times

item.title: Trump Abandons Efforts to Deploy National Guard to 3 Major Cities
item.description: The troops had nearly no presence in two of the cities, Portland and Chicago. But the decision signaled a retreat, at least for now, in one of the president’s most audacious attempts to test his power.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Alex Welsh for The New York Times
item.media:description: National Guard troops in Los Angeles in June. President Trump abandoned his effort to deploy the Guard there on Wednesday.

item.title: Trump Vetoes 2 Bills, Drawing Accusations of Retaliation
item.description: The president said he blocked the bills to save taxpayers’ money. But he has grievances against a tribe in Florida and officials in Colorado.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump’s two vetoes were the first of his second term.

item.title: Trump’s Veto of Water Project Is His Latest Targeted Hit on Colorado
item.description: The president seems to be at war with the Democratic-led state as he raises the pressure on Colorado leaders to release a convicted election denier, Tina Peters, from state prison.
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy
item.media:credit: RJ Sangosti/The Denver Post, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The Arkansas Valley Conduit would provide clean water to 50,000 Colorado residents by diverting water from the Arkansas River, seen here at the base of the dam of the Pueblo Reservoir.

item.title: Ukraine Did Not Target Putin’s Home, C.I.A. Finds
item.description: The assessment rebutted a claim that the Russian leader made to President Trump in a phone call this week.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Eric Schmitt and Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine called Russia’s claim “a complete fabrication intended to justify additional attacks against Ukraine, including Kyiv, as well as Russia’s own refusal to take necessary steps to end the war.”

item.title: Coast Guard Searches for Survivors After More Boat Strikes
item.description: The U.S. military attacked a convoy of three boats in the eastern Pacific on Tuesday, and two more on Wednesday, as part of the Trump administration’s campaign against people suspected of drug trafficking.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:credit: Miguel J. Rodriguez Carrillo/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A Coast Guard cutter in San Juan, P.R. An undetermined number of people survived strikes by the U.S. military on boats in the Pacific Ocean on Tuesday.

item.title: Oil Tanker Fleeing the Coast Guard Now Listed in Russian Ship Database
item.description: The listing could make it more challenging for U.S. forces to board the ship, which an arm of the Kremlin’s maritime authority says is now flying the Russian flag.
item.dc:creator: Christiaan Triebert and Nicholas Nehamas
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Department of Homeland Security, via Reuters
item.media:description: A U.S. military helicopter flying over the Panama-flagged Centuries, which was intercepted in the Caribbean Sea. American officials have suggested that they intend to seize another ship, Bella 1, which they are currently tracking.

item.title: Venezuela Detains U.S. Citizens Amid Trump Administration’s Growing Pressure
item.description: The number of American citizens held in Venezuela has grown since the start of the U.S. military and economic campaign against President Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Annie Correal and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela at a rally in Caracas, the capital, earlier this month.

item.title: Most of Iran Shuts Down as Government Grapples With Protests and Economy
item.description: Amid mounting street protests, businesses, universities and government offices stayed closed Wednesday under government orders, in 21 of 31 provinces, including Tehran.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni and Sanam Mahoozi
item.media:credit: Atta Kenare/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Tehran on Wednesday as businesses, universities and most government offices were told to close.

item.title: Suicide Bomber in Syria Kills Security Officer in New Year’s Eve Attack
item.description: The attacker likely had links to the Islamic State and was possibly targeting a Christian church in the center of Aleppo, according to a government spokesman.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni and Hussam Hammoud
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Mahmoud Hassano/Reuters
item.media:description: A view of Aleppo, Syria, where a suicide bomber struck on Wednesday.

item.title: Behind Oklahoma Cannabis Farms, New Yorkers With Ties to Beijing
item.description: In China, trafficking marijuana is punishable by death. But in the United States, it has become a lucrative sideline for some favored sons of the motherland.
item.dc:creator: Jay Root, Bianca Pallaro, Michael Forsythe and Shuran Huang
item.media:credit: Shuran Huang for The New York Times

item.title: Tatiana Schlossberg Submitted a Heartbreaking Essay to The New Yorker on Her Cancer Diagnosis, Fully Formed
item.description: When Tatiana Schlossberg submitted an essay to The New Yorker, it had not been assigned or even expected. It was accepted immediately and barely edited.
item.dc:creator: Jesse McKinley
item.media:credit: Amber De Vos/Getty Images
item.media:description: Tatiana Schlossberg’s essay for The New Yorker, published online in November and in print this month, moved David Remnick, the magazine’s editor, with its “heart and intelligence and honesty,” he said.

item.title: Brigitte Bardot’s Legacy of Racist Rhetoric
item.description: The actress, who died this week at 91, was an icon of 1960s cinema. She was also a hero to the French far right.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.media:credit: Pascal Pavani/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Brigitte Bardot, center, appeared in court in 1997 on charges of inciting racial hatred.

item.title: Brigitte Bardot Was the Face of a Nation
item.description: A star who never played coy for the camera was once an emblem of France.
item.dc:creator: Rhonda Garelick
item.media:credit: Sunset Boulevard/Corbis, via Getty Images
item.media:description: She was an original 1950s bombshell, alongside Sophia Loren, Gina Lollobrigida, Jayne Mansfield and Marilyn Monroe.

item.title: The Top Movies of 2025, According to Times Readers: ‘Marty Supreme’ and More
item.description: We asked you to vote on the best films of the year. The results ranged from big box office hits to small art-house indies.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Goodman
item.category: Come See Me in the Good Light (Movie)
If I Had Legs I'd Kick You (Movie)
Wake Up Dead Man: A Knives Out Mystery (Movie)

item.title: Historic Snowstorm Blankets Syracuse Just in Time for the New Year
item.description: Syracuse, N.Y., has received nearly twice its usual monthly amount of snow in December.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk and Samantha Latson
item.media:credit: Rylee Kirk/The New York Times
item.media:description: A street in Syracuse’s downtown area, known as Armory Square, was still covered in snow after the city’s second snowiest day on record.

item.title: A Trump Security Is Empty, Mr. Zelensky
item.description: Ukraine’s president should stop pressing for U.S. security guarantees and pursue more effective means of self-protection.
item.dc:creator: Philip H. Gordon
item.media:credit: Alex Brandon/Associated Press

item.title: Why New York City Needs Someone Like Mamdani
item.description: The new mayor is an entirely familiar type of New York politician.
item.dc:creator: Kim Phillips-Fein
item.media:credit:
Photo illustration by The New York Times. Source photographs by Bettmann/Getty Images;
Damon Winter/The New York Times.

item.title: A Farewell Ride With the MetroCard, on Every Transit Line That Uses It
item.description: Two Times journalists joined Miles Taylor, a YouTuber and transport enthusiast, on a daylong journey across New York City area buses and trains before sale of the card ends on Dec. 31.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather
item.media:credit: Vincent Alban/The New York Times

item.title: In Chief Justice’s Annual Report, a History Lesson and Embrace of Independence
item.description: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. did not directly address the tensions between the Trump administration and federal judges who have blocked the president’s agenda.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow
item.media:credit: Eric Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. in May. By tradition, he releases his report about the state of the nation’s courts on the last day of the year.

item.title: Manhattan Man, 80, Faces Homicide Charge After Sidewalk Shoving
item.description: Dana Escoffier was indicted on a charge of criminally negligent homicide in the death of Dean Whetzel, 82, a neighbor whom he had known for decades.
item.dc:creator: Miles G. Cohen
item.media:credit: Richard Perry/The New York Times
item.media:description: Dana Escoffier in his West Village apartment in 2000.

item.title: Jacqueline de Ribes, Tastemaker and Fashion Avatar, Dies at 96
item.description: One of few people in the world of style who could legitimately claim the status of icon, she dressed to impress even before she became a designer.
item.dc:creator: Ruth La Ferla
item.media:credit: Horst P. Horst/Condé Nast, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Jacqueline de Ribes in 1953. She designed clothes for herself and for a socially prominent clientele.
